description: From Middle English present, from Old French present, from Latin praesent-, praesens present participle of praeesse (“to be present”), from Latin prae- (“pre-”) + esse (“to be”).

adjectives.description: present (comparative more present, superlative most present)

entries.meaning: Relating to now, for the time being; current.
examples: The barbaric practice continues to the present day.The present manager has been here longer than the last one.Up to the present day.

entries.meaning: Located in the immediate vicinity.
examples: Is there a doctor present?  Several people were present when the event took place.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Having an immediate effect (of a medicine, poison etc.); fast-acting. [16th–18th c.]
examples: Amongſt this number of Cordials and Alteratiues, J doe not find a more preſent remedy, then a cup of wine, or ſtrong drinke, and if it be ſoberly and opportunely vſed.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Not delayed; immediate; instant.
(dated) Ready; quick in emergency.
examples: a present wit

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Favorably attentive; propitious.
examples: to find a god so present to my prayer

entries.meaning: Relating to something a person is referring to in the very context, with a deictic use similar to the demonstrative adjective this.
examples: in the present study,  the present article,  the present results.

entries.meaning: Attentive; alert; focused.
examples: Sorry, I was distracted just now, I'll try to be more present from now on.

entries.meaning: (politics) Neither for or against (used in voting to express abstention)
The current moment or period of time.
(grammar) The present tense.

description: From Middle English presenten, from Old French presenter, from Latin praesentāre (“to show”), from praesent-, praesens, present participle of praeesse (“be in front of”).

entries.meaning: A gift, especially one given for birthdays, Christmas, anniversaries, graduations, weddings, or any other special occasions.
(military) The position of a soldier in presenting arms.
examples: to stand at present

verbs.description: present (third-person singular simple present presents, present participle presenting, simple past and past participle presented)

entries.meaning: To bring (someone) into the presence of (a person); to introduce formally. [from 14th c.]
examples: to present an envoy to the king

entries.meaning: (transitive) To nominate (a member of the clergy) for an ecclesiastical benefice; to offer to the bishop or ordinary as a candidate for institution. [from 14th c.]
(transitive) To offer (a problem, complaint) to a court or other authority for consideration. [from 14th c.]
(transitive, now rare) To charge (a person) with a crime or accusation; to bring before court. [from 14th c.]
examples: In the diocese of Gloucester in 1548 two inhabitants of Slimbridge were presented for saying that holy oil was ‘of no virtue but meet to grease sheep’.

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To come forward, appear in a particular place or before a particular person, especially formally. [from 14th c.]
(transitive) To put (something) forward in order for it to be seen; to show, exhibit. [from 14th c.]
examples: Note: The offensive team must present a legal formation both before and after a shift.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make clear to one's mind or intelligence; to put forward for consideration. [from 14th c.]
examples: I do begin to realize that the matter must be presented in such a way as may interest the reader.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put on, stage (a play etc.). [from 16th c.]
examples: The theater is proud to present the Fearless Fliers.

entries.meaning: (transitive, military) To point (a firearm) at something, to hold (a weapon) in a position ready to fire. [from 16th c.]
(reflexive) To offer oneself for mental consideration; to occur to the mind. [from 16th c.]
examples: Well, one idea does present itself.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, medicine) To come to the attention of medical staff, especially with a specific symptom. [from 19th c.]
examples: The patient presented with insomnia.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, medicine) To appear (in a specific way) for delivery (of a fetus); to appear first at the mouth of the uterus during childbirth. [from 18th c.]
(intransitive, with "as") To appear or represent oneself (as having a certain gender).
examples: At that time, Elbe was presenting as a man.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To act as presenter on (a radio, television programme etc.). [from 20th c.]
examples: Anne Robinson presents "The Weakest Link".

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give a gift or presentation to (someone). [from 14th c.]
examples: She was presented with an honorary degree for her services to entertainment.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give (a gift or presentation) to someone; to bestow. [from 14th c.]
examples: My last, least offering, I present thee now.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To deliver (something abstract) as though as a gift; to offer. [from 14th c.]
examples: I presented my compliments to Lady Featherstoneshaw.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hand over (a bill etc.) to be paid. [from 15th c.]
(intransitive, zoology) To display one's female genitalia in a way that signals to others that one is ready for copulation. Also referred to as lordosis behaviour. [from 20th c.]
(fandom slang) In omegaverse fiction, to have one's secondary sex (alpha, omega, or beta) become apparent, typically at puberty. [from 21st c.]
examples: Sherlock’s gender performance itself remains unchanged, with the exception of the hormonal changes he goes through after presenting as an omega.
